stream_context.summary: Kaze showcased progress on an ice castle level, discussing platforming design and visual polish. The majority of the stream was a deep technical collaboration with guest developer Sauraen to integrate and test the F3DX3 microcode, resulting in significant performance improvements for the game.

development_findings.summary: Due to extensive RDP (graphics) optimizations, the game's primary performance bottleneck has shifted to the RSP (CPU), a reversal of the commonly understood N64 performance limitations.
development_findings.quote: It is also interesting to note that for like the last 28 years I was like well the reason the N64 is slow is because of fill rate and memory throughput and now we're at this point and actually it's the RSP.

development_findings.summary: Kaze officially decided to adopt the F3DX3 microcode developed by Sauraen, which provides significant performance gains, fixing a frame drop from 28 to a stable 30 FPS in a demanding scene.
development_findings.quote: I'm just gonna add the lighting support which I'm probably gonna do later today for emulator hopefully I can do that with self-modifying code so I don't have to shit up my eye cache and then I think we're all good.

development_findings.summary: Sauraen's F3DX3 microcode features an auto-batching capability that dramatically improves performance by preventing the reloading of identical materials, saving 3 milliseconds of texture loading time in a scene with many rabbits.

Kaze plans to use different microcodes on a per-level basis, swapping between the standard F3DX3 and a version with occlusion culling depending on which is more performant for a given scene's geometry.
A bug causing corrupted text in the on-screen profiler was traced to legacy code for rainbow-colored text, which was removed to fix the issue.
Platforming for the ice castle level (Course 13) is complete, with work now focused on visual polish and texturing.
The game is planned to have 12 levels with 7 stars each, plus some extras, for a total of around 90-100 stars.
Kaze implemented a visual effect where objects fade into view using a dither pattern combined with threshold alpha that is manipulated based on distance.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has strong negative opinions about the development practices of Rare, criticizing their optimization in Banjo-Kazooie and Conker's Bad Fur Day, and what he perceives as hypocrisy from the developers.
context_findings.quote: Being such a snobby asshole. And then you don't even live up to your own standards. Fuck you.

context_findings.summary: Kaze dislikes the gameplay loop of JRPGs, citing Final Fantasy VII as an example where he enjoys the world but finds the combat tedious, even with a fast-forward feature.
context_findings.quote: The game has a really cool vibe. It's really fun to just exist in the world. But goddamn, I hate JRPGs.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds Majora's Mask in very high regard, believing its unique mechanics and structure give it lasting value that even a modern classic like Breath of the Wild doesn't supersede.
context_findings.quote: Majora's mask is the only Zelda game that Breath of the Wild did not make obsolete.

context_findings.summary: Kaze and his wife, Zeina, recently became parents. Their baby was with its grandparents during the stream.

biobak.summary: Biobak was present in the chat. Kaze complimented one of Biobak's floor textures, calling it "really nice".

zeina.summary: Zeina is creating assets for an upcoming outdoor area described as a "little village with penguin huts".
Zeina was present during the stream, participating in conversations, for example about the name of the artist Femtanyl.

key_stories.title: The F3DX3 Microcode Integration
key_stories.summary: Kaze collaborated with microcode developer Sauraen to integrate the new F3DX3 microcode. This addressed a major performance bottleneck that had shifted from the RDP to the RSP due to Kaze's prior optimizations. The collaboration resulted in significant performance gains, fixing a major frame drop and unlocking further potential for the game.
key_stories.challenge: A demanding scene with many animated rabbits was causing the frame rate to drop to 28 FPS, bottlenecked by the RSP (CPU) rather than the typical RDP (graphics).
key_stories.process: Kaze brought Sauraen, the creator of the F3DX3 microcode, onto the stream. Sauraen explained how he optimized F3DX3 by rewriting vertex processing and fixing inefficiencies in Nintendo's original code. They live-tested different versions, debugged a text rendering issue, and quantified the significant performance gains.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze officially adopted F3DX3. The microcode's superior efficiency and auto-batching features fixed the frame drop, bringing it to a stable 30 FPS, and provided a 3ms reduction in texture load times in that scene.
key_stories.key_quote: It is also interesting to note that for like the last 28 years I was like well the reason the n64 is slow is because of fill rate and memory throughput and now we're at this point and actually it's the rsp.

key_stories.title: Kaze's Rant on Rare
key_stories.summary: Kaze went on a detailed rant about his negative opinions of developer Rare. He criticized their technical choices in Banjo-Kazooie and Conker's Bad Fur Day, and recounted a story of what he perceived as developer hypocrisy, revealing his own deeply-held values about game optimization and design integrity.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze's rant against Rare's development practices revealed his strong principles on technical optimization and developer integrity.
key_stories.process: Prompted by a mention of Banjo-Kazooie, Kaze criticized Rare for inefficient practices like decompressing code during gameplay. He specifically recounted watching a 'devs play' of Conker's Bad Fur Day where the developers stated a design principle (characters pushing against walls) that their own game then violated moments later without acknowledgement.
key_stories.outcome: The rant provides a clear window into Kaze's development philosophy: a deep respect for technical efficiency and a disdain for developers who he feels don't live up to their own stated standards or who release poorly optimized games.
key_stories.key_quote: Being such a snobby asshole. And then you don't even live up to your own standards. Fuck you.

key_stories.title: Rabbit Model Optimization
key_stories.summary: While diagnosing performance, Kaze and Sauraen discovered that the rabbit models were highly inefficient. However, Sauraen's F3DX3 microcode automatically batched the redundant material loads, providing a massive 3-millisecond performance improvement without any changes to the asset itself. This incident became a key proof-of-concept for the power of F3DX3.
key_stories.challenge: An animated rabbit model was revealed to be highly unoptimized, reloading the same material 14 times per instance, which should have caused major performance issues.
key_stories.process: While testing F3DX3, Sauraen and Kaze investigated the performance of a scene with many rabbits. They discovered that F3DX3's auto-batching feature was providing a massive performance boost. This led to an examination of the rabbit's geometry file, which confirmed it was reloading materials inefficiently for each limb. The team briefly discussed alternative optimization methods before concluding F3DX3's solution was sufficient for now.
key_stories.outcome: The auto-batching feature in F3DX3 was so effective that it automatically mitigated the poorly optimized model, saving 3ms of texture loading time. While Kaze still plans to fix the model, the microcode provided a powerful, automatic solution, demonstrating its value.
key_stories.key_quote: Look at this, text is 2.2. It's literally a 3 millisecond difference.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned Zeina is creating assets for a 'little village with penguin huts'. This is the first time this area has been described.
questions: What is the concept behind the penguin village?
Zeina, what is your creative process for designing these assets? What's the feeling you're trying to evoke?
How does the artistic collaboration between you and Kaze work? How do you handle feedback and iteration on assets like these?

open_questions.context: Sauraen explained that Kaze's RDP optimizations were so effective that the game's bottleneck shifted to the RSP. This is a fundamental change from how N64 performance has been understood for decades.
questions: Kaze, can you walk us through the key RDP optimizations you implemented that led to this bottleneck shift?
What was the 'aha' moment when you realized the performance problem was no longer the RDP, but the RSP?
How does this change in understanding N64 limitations affect your overall approach to designing levels and features for the rest of the project?

open_questions.context: Kaze has decided to use F3DX3 and plans to implement it with emulator compatibility in mind, potentially using self-modifying code and swapping microcodes on a per-level basis.
questions: Could you explain the strategy for using self-modifying code to maintain emulator compatibility? What are the technical challenges involved?
How will you decide which levels use the occlusion-culling version of the microcode versus the standard one?
Sauraen, from your perspective, what does it mean for your work to be adopted by a project of this scale? What future possibilities does this open up?

open_questions.context: Kaze expressed very strong, principled opinions on the work of other developers (Rare) and genres (JRPGs).
questions: How do your strong opinions on what makes a 'good' or 'bad' game directly influence your design choices in Return to Yoshi's Island?
You've talked about what you dislike in other games. What games are you drawing positive inspiration from for this project?
How do you balance respecting the original SM64 while also injecting your own, very distinct design philosophy?
